awd_titl_txt: Building a Hawaiian Spoken Language Digital Repository
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of understanding the range of human linguistic features and the limits on their distribution requires in-depth data sets from each language in order to make and test scientifically valid hypotheses. This study will contribute to that major goal by creating a digital corpus of speech and transcripts of an endangered language for which no corpus currently exists. The corpus will result in a large publicly available data set, available for researchers to make new queries or to test the reproducibility of prior findings. This will foster robust and reliable research on a diversity of subjects. Broader impacts include the integration of this corpus into immersion-based language education from pre-school to university and into the curriculum of the natural sciences and beyond. The project will also engage underrepresented groups as citizen scientists and will create a publicly available corpus of an endangered Indigenous U.S. language, Hawaiian. The Native American Languages Act, passed by the U.S. Congress in 1990, enacted into policy the recognition of the unique status and importance of the indigenous languages of the U.S.  In addition, the project will broaden participation in the social sciences by the training of Native Hawaiian language scholars and is co-funded by the NSF Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP).

In this project, the team will build Kani'âina, the digital archive of recordings and transcripts of spoken Native Hawaiian. Summarily, Kani'âina will be a digital repository that will (i) allow interactive access to an estimated 900-1200 hours of extant recordings of spoken Native Hawaiian and transcripts through a bilingual digital library interface that is already arguably the single most-accessed site for Hawaiian language materials; (ii) properly preserve those recordings and transcripts permanently in a world-class OLAC-compliant digital archive (thus making them discoverable to other scientists); (iii) implement a procedure for crowd-sourced transcription of additional recordings from e.g. the public and from University of Hawai'i students of Hawaiian language; and (iv) serve as a catalyst for a cross-campus graduate educational exchange between students at two campuses of the University of Hawai'i. The project will use participatory archiving of language documentation, enabling the public to access and contribute to the transcription and content-tagging of recordings of spoken language. Project activities include the transcription and content-tagging of recordings of spoken language.  The merit and impact of this project center on the kinds of information that are encoded in the recordings themselves. Making this information freely available will in turn make a wide range of scientific and ethno-scientific topics accessible and will be revolutionary for STEM education on Hawaiian subjects, including linguistics, ecological knowledge, environmental sustainability, and the historical anthropology of the Hawaiian islands. This project is a cross-campus collaboration between the University of Hawai'i at Hilo, a US Department of Education Native Hawaiian Serving Institution and the University of Hawai'i at Mânoa.

por.por_cntn:
In the early 1800's, Hawaiian was flourishing in Hawaii. However, in 1985, there were less than 50 children who were fluent in the language. This was an impetus for the Hawaiian language revitalization movement seeking to ensure the survival of the language. There have been many efforts over the past three decades that have proven successful as an international model of language revitalization through family-based education initiatives and Hawaiian language medium-immersion schools from pre-school to university. As an essential element of this language revitalization story, Kaniaina has made great strides in making the leo (voices) of kupuna manaleo (native speaking elders), most of whom have long since passed away, available to the next generation of Hawaiian speakers.

Today, Kaniaina provides one of the largest centralized, accessible repositories for the preservation and access of digital documentation of spoken Hawaiian by the native speaker generation and plays a key role in Hawaiian language preservation, access,and mobilization for education and research. Kaniaina brings to light not only the linguistic features of spoken Hawaiian but also a view of the natural world through the lens of Indigenous Hawaiian ecological knowledge passed down from the elders.

Some specific resources that Kaniaina provides include a bilingual website at www.ulukau.org/kaniaina that hosts those kupuna manaleo voices and allows for access to rich archives that previously were hard to reach or inaccessible to the general public. Currently, there are a total of four collections consisting of the Ka Leo Hawaii and Ku i ka Manaleo audio programs and the recently added Manaleo TV and Na Hulu Kupuna video series. These four collections represent 655 hours of priceless content available freely online to the families of those kupuna, schools, and the community at large.

The impact on the community has been evidenced by a number of scholarly articles and books about education, Native Hawaiian agency and history, linguistics, and more citing Kaniaina recordings as primary sources. Multiple young Hawaiians living away from their home islands have also deemed Kaniaina as an essential resource and tool for reclaiming their mother tongue and teaching themselves Hawaiian. These archives have also been incorporated into curriculum for many classes across the various University of Hawaii campuses, as well as online community-based language learning programs facilitating teaching and learning about language and cultural topics. The Ka Leo Hawaiʻi collection also includes a crowdsourcing feature that is as also an excellent training tool for developing listening and transcription skills.

Additionally, archival work has been done and continues to be done behind the scenes to search for, acquire, digitize, index, and prepare many more hours of Hawaiian language native speaker recordings for eventual release to the public in addition to the collections available online now. To date, just over 1,135 hours of native Hawaiian audio and video recordings have been processed by the project with the intention of providing access to these additional collections in the future. This work has also provided many undergraduate students at the University of Hawaii at Hilo with the opportunity to learn about archiving and preservation, as well as strengthening their knowledge of the Hawaiian language and culture by listening and learning from the interviews they work with. Furthermore, these hands-on work experiences present opportunities to grow as future language revitalization leaders through one-on-one interaction with senior Kaniaina project members who are pioneers of the Hawaiian revitalization movement.

There remain many hours of archives left to be curated, as well as technological tasks such as finalizing the last steps of a tagging and transcription crowdsourcing, in the near future. However, Kaniaina has already proven itself as a valuable community resource that houses and makes accessible an important part of Hawaiian heritage that benefits the continued survival of the Hawaiian language and identity in this day and age through education and research.
